Introduction

Erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease, is a manifestation of parvovirus B19 infection that presents as a common childhood viral exanthem.  Although rare, adults can also develop erythema infectiosum following parvovirus B19 infection.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



Parvovirus B19 is a nonenveloped, single-stranded DNA virus that replicates in erythroid progenitor cells.  Only these cells express the cell surface receptor for parvovirus B19 (P blood group antigen).  Infection prevents erythroid progenitor cell maturation, leading to the formation of giant pronormoblasts (much larger than normal red blood cells [RBCs]) with glassy, intranuclear viral inclusions (

image 1
).  Viral replication induces erythroid progenitor cell lysis, temporarily halting erythropoiesis.



Most patients remain asymptomatic because the remaining RBCs have a lifespan of several months.  However, even brief interruptions in RBC production can cause severe anemia (eg, transient aplastic crisis) in patients with underlying hematologic disorders with accelerated RBC turnover (eg, sickle cell anemia).



A few factors appear to increase the risk for erythema infectiosum, including:



  • Age 5-15.
  • Season:  late winter and early spring.
  • Exposure:  close contacts of infected individuals, particularly in school or day care settings.
  • Immune status:  individuals who are immunocompromised (eg, patients with HIV) and those with underlying hematologic disorders (eg, sickle cell disease).  In addition, these patients are at increased risk for severe complications (ie, transient aplastic crisis).

Clinical presentation



The clinical presentation of parvovirus B19 infection varies, with 25% of patients remaining asymptomatic.  In symptomatic patients, erythema infectiosum classically presents in 3 stages (

figure 1
), after an incubation period of 7-14 days, as follows:



  • Prodrome:  A total of 2-4 days of nonspecific, flu-like symptoms (eg, fever, malaise, cough, congestion) coinciding with viremia and any hematologic abnormalities (eg, anemia, reticulocytopenia) that may occur.
  • Exanthem:
    • Face:  Malar rash that spares the nasolabial fold, or slapped-cheek appearance (
      image 2
      ), with circumoral pallor.
    • Body:  Maculopapular rash that spreads to the trunk and limbs, often with a lacy, reticulated pattern (
      image 3
      ), which occurs several days after the malar rash.
  • Recovery:  Exanthem that typically resolves in 1-3 weeks but may recur with exposure to sunlight, heat, stress, etc.


Only 25% of patients develop an exanthem, which often prompts presentation to medical care.  The exanthem is immune mediated, and patients are not considered to be infectious once the exanthem appears.  The exanthem is generally benign, and patients are often well-appearing.  Although more common in adults, arthralgias and/or arthritis occur in 10% of children with the exanthem.

Diagnosis



Erythema infectiosum is a clinical diagnosis based on the characteristic rash and history.  However, when necessary, the diagnosis can be confirmed with laboratory testing, as follows:



  • Serology:  This is the preferred confirmatory test.  Immunocompromised patients, however, may not have detectable antibodies due to an insufficient immune response.
  • PCR:  Detection of parvovirus B19 DNA via PCR may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis in immunocompromised patients; however, parvovirus B19 DNA can be detected for months to years after acute infection and therefore may not distinguish acute from chronic infections.  Additionally, since erythema infectiosum is an immune-mediated exanthem, most patients have already mounted an immune response at the time of presentation, and parvovirus B19 DNA may not be detectable.


If performed, a complete blood count may show anemia without compensatory reticulocytosis.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for erythema infectiosum includes:



  • Measles:  patients are often ill-appearing with a viral prodrome (eg, fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, Koplik spots) followed by a cephalocaudal maculopapular rash (
    image 4
    ).  However, patients with erythema infectiosum are typically well-appearing and do not develop conjunctivitis.
  • Scarlet fever:  a delayed-type skin reaction to Streptococcus pyogenes that presents with fever, pharyngitis, and a fine, papular (sandpaper) rash that starts in the axillae or groin and spreads to the trunk and extremities (
    image 5
    ).
  • Kawasaki disease:  classically presents with â‰¥5 days of fever in addition to conjunctivitis, rash, lymphadenopathy, and extremity changes.  In contrast, erythema infectiosum is characterized by a brief (2-4 days) prodrome with fever, malaise, cough, and congestion but no conjunctivitis, lymphadenopathy, or extremity changes.


In addition to measles, the differential diagnosis also includes other viral exanthems, including roseola, rubella, and enteroviral infections.  These diagnoses may be distinguished by rash morphology and distribution, as well as associated symptoms and vaccination history.

Management



Erythema infectiosum is a mild, self-limited viral illness.  Treatment is supportive with antipyretics and analgesics as needed.  The majority of patients fully recover within weeks of symptom onset.

Complications



Although rare, potential complications of erythema infectiosum can include:



  • Transient aplastic crisis:  Acute parvovirus B19 infection can cause severe anemia in patients with underlying hematologic disorders that rely on continuous erythropoiesis (eg, hereditary spherocytosis).  These patients often require hospitalization and serial RBC transfusions.
  • Chronic infection:  Immunocompromised patients who are unable to produce neutralizing antibodies can develop severe, chronic anemia.  These patients may benefit from intravenous immunoglobulin therapy.
  • Hydrops fetalis:  Parvovirus B19 infection during pregnancy can affect fetal progenitor cells.  This can lead to fetal anemia and hydrops fetalis with a risk for fetal demise, particularly before 20 weeks gestation.

Summary



Erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease, is a manifestation of parvovirus B19 infection that presents as a common childhood viral exanthem.  Patients develop a brief (2-4 days) viral prodrome (eg, fever, malaise, cough, congestion) followed by a malar rash (slapped-cheek appearance).  The infection is mild and self-limited, and management is supportive.  Although rare, complications can include transient aplastic crisis in patients with underlying hematologic disorders, chronic infection in patients with immunodeficiencies, and hydrops fetalis in pregnant women.
